channel.title: W3schools certification any good?
channel.description:
http://www.w3schools.com/cert/
Is this legit? I mean anybody could cheat and literally have the certificate given to them. Is it worth getting them from w3schools?
I scored 100% in the JS practice test when I have 0 knowledge of it lmao and like 80% in the SQL one because of deathchaos's highscore tut lmao
They let you take the test anywhere you want as long as you got somebody making sure you don't cheat e.g. boss or teacher.
What would you say?

item.title: W3schools certification any good?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Sorry, that was more of a personal opinion rather than a valid one LoL Just how I think that degrees are just a piece of paper, especially if you have no real world knowledge.

Read full topic

item.title: W3schools certification any good?
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

Pwnd:

Those certs are pretty much either to fool people that don’t know, or for personal pride. I wouldn’t spend the money.

Agreed.

Pwnd:

Certs are for nerds anyways. If you have the abilities, you also have the ability to prove yourself without pieces of paper saying “Yeah, I might be qualified”.

100% disagree. Certs from CompTIA, Cisco and Microsoft are all very valuable to most companies.

That being said… A person with every certificate in the world could be less knowledgeable than some frank_ off the street who’s been on the pc their entire life. But to a company the certs are a way to easily prove that knowledge.

Read full topic

item.title: W3schools certification any good?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:7, topic:535585”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=654390.msg4383663#msg4383663 date=1384454062]
Certs are for nerds anyways. If you have the abilities, you also have the ability to prove yourself without pieces of paper saying “Yeah, I might be qualified”.
[/quote]

except any real company that’s not a startup is going to look for certs.[/quote]
Yeah, from recognised bodies (i.e., universities, trade schools, and other qualification providers that are formally recognised). W3schools is just a reference website.

Read full topic

item.title: W3schools certification any good?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

I didn’t think it was a reconsigned certificate anyway (if it was I’d go for every single one lmao) but it was a cheaper alternative then to going to places like Microsoft who charge roughly over £100.

I’m personally not going to go for it mainly because I wouldn’t trust using it practically for a job.

Read full topic

item.title: W3schools certification any good?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

I’m not sure the usefulness of the certificate in a workplace relating to website design and development since I work in a completely different walk of life but it’s always something else to add to your CV. I mean, you’d be spending about £60 on a certificate that may not help you get your foot in the door to a line of work relating to this but if you have the money spare then go ahead. It is recommended by quite a few universities and as a few of my friends attend Dundee and a shit ton of them tried to get in then I’d say it’s a pretty prestigious university. Like I said, if you have the money spare then I don’t see why not but if it was me I’d rather attend some form of night class at a local college or something like that and speak to the lecturer, see what they have to say. Failing that just send a few emails to local firms and see what their stance on it is.

Lothy may be able to help on this since I think he’s the only person here who actually works as a website developer.

Read full topic
